doc_description: This document is a legal memorandum and order from the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts regarding cross-motions for summary judgment and a motion for leave to file a third-party complaint in a case involving MSP Recovery Claims, Series LLC, and Massachusetts Bay Insurance Company, among others. The case concerns the reimbursement of medical expenses under the Medicare Secondary Payer Act.

structure.title: Introduction
structure.summary: The document is a court order addressing cross-motions for summary judgment and a motion for leave to file a third-party complaint. The case involves MSP Recovery Claims, Series LLC, and Massachusetts Bay Insurance Company, among others, concerning reimbursement of medical expenses under the Medicare Secondary Payer Act.
structure.text: This is a dispute concerning reimbursement of certain medical expenses pursuant to the Medicare Secondary Payer Act of 1980, 42 U.S.C. § 1395y(b) et seq. Plaintiff MSP Recovery Claims, Series LLC is the assignee of Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts, a health insurer. Defendants Massachusetts Bay Insurance Company and Citizens Insurance Company of America are property and casualty insurers that sell, among other products, automobile insurance.

structure.title: Background
structure.summary: The background section provides details about the parties involved, the statutory framework of the Medicare Secondary Payer Act, and the factual background of the claims involving A.D. and P.R. It also outlines the procedural history of the case.
structure.text: The following facts are undisputed unless otherwise noted. MSPRC is a Delaware series limited liability company. It is the assignee of Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts as to the claims asserted in this lawsuit. BCBSMA is a Massachusetts health insurer and a Medicare Advantage Organization. Defendant Massachusetts Bay is an insurance company located in Massachusetts that issues liability and no-fault insurance policies.

nodes.title: The Parties
nodes.summary: This subsection identifies the parties involved in the case, including MSP Recovery Claims, Series LLC, Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts, Massachusetts Bay Insurance Company, and Citizens Insurance Company of America.
nodes.text: MSPRC is a Delaware series limited liability company. It is the assignee of Blue Cross Blue Shield of Massachusetts as to the claims asserted in this lawsuit. BCBSMA is a Massachusetts health insurer and a Medicare Advantage Organization.

nodes.title: The Statutory Framework
nodes.summary: This subsection explains the Medicare Secondary Payer Act, which establishes that Medicare is a secondary payer when a primary plan is responsible for payment. It outlines the conditions under which Medicare can make conditional payments and the obligation of primary plans to reimburse Medicare.
nodes.text: Congress enacted the Medicare Secondary Payer Act in 1980. Under the Act, if both Medicare and a private insurer cover the same eligible expense, the private insurer would be the primary source of payment and Medicare the secondary option.

nodes.title: Factual Background
nodes.summary: This subsection provides details about the specific claims involving A.D. and P.R., including the assignment of claims, the insurance policies involved, and the actions taken by the parties.
nodes.text: On December 18, 2018, BCBSMA assigned to MSP Recovery, LLC its recovery and reimbursement rights under the MSP Act for a specific set of claims. P.R.’s and A.D.’s claims were included in that assignment.

structure.title: Cross-Motions for Summary Judgment
structure.summary: This section discusses the legal standard for summary judgment and analyzes the cross-motions for summary judgment filed by the parties. It addresses the claims against Massachusetts Bay and Citizens, as well as the breach-of-contract claim.
structure.text: The role of summary judgment is to pierce the pleadings and to assess the proof in order to see whether there is a genuine need for trial. Summary judgment shall be granted when there is no genuine dispute as to any material fact and the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.

nodes.title: Legal Standard
nodes.summary: This subsection outlines the legal standard for summary judgment, which is granted when there is no genuine dispute as to any material fact and the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.
nodes.text: The role of summary judgment is to pierce the pleadings and to assess the proof in order to see whether there is a genuine need for trial. Summary judgment shall be granted when there is no genuine dispute as to any material fact and the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.

nodes.title: Analysis
nodes.summary: This subsection analyzes the cross-motions for summary judgment, addressing the MSP-Act claim against Massachusetts Bay, the breach-of-contract claim, and the MSP-Act claim against Citizens.
nodes.text: The MSP Act establishes a private cause of action for damages in the case of a primary plan which fails to provide for primary payment or appropriate reimbursement. Plaintiff contends that Massachusetts Bay is a primary plan that improperly failed to reimburse BCBSMA for payments made to cover medical care provided to A.D.

structure.title: Motion for Leave to File Third-Party Complaint
structure.summary: This section addresses Citizens' motion for leave to file a third-party complaint seeking indemnification from P.R. The court denies the motion due to the late stage of the litigation and the minimal prejudice to Citizens.
structure.text: Citizens has moved for leave to file a third-party complaint seeking indemnification from P.R. pursuant to its settlement agreement. Given the late stage of the litigation—the claims currently before the Court will be resolved upon issuance of this order—and the minimal resulting prejudice that Citizens might suffer in being required to pursue indemnification in a separate action, the motion will be denied.

structure.title: Conclusion
structure.summary: The court grants summary judgment in favor of defendants on Counts 1 and 2, and in favor of the plaintiff on Count 3. Citizens' motion for leave to file a third-party complaint is denied, and damages are awarded to the plaintiff.
structure.text: For the foregoing reasons, plaintiff’s motion for summary judgment is DENIED as to Count 1 and GRANTED as to Count 3; defendants’ motion for summary judgment is GRANTED as to Counts 1 and 2, and DENIED as to Count 3; and defendant Citizens Insurance Company of America’s motion for leave to file a third-party complaint is DENIED. Damages are hereby awarded to plaintiff on Count 3 in the amount of $38,846.90.
